author: Peter Loftus
title: Appeals Court Strikes Down Maryland’s Drug-Price-Gouging Law
text:
A federal appeals court on Friday struck down a Maryland law barring generic-drug companies from price gouging, finding that the law violates the Constitution’s commerce clause, which reserves for Congress the power to regulate interstate commerce.
Judges for U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond, Va., wrote the Maryland law “would impose a significant burden on interstate commerce involving prescription drugs.” They reversed a lower-court ruling upholding the Maryland law in a lawsuit filed last year by...
